item.title: Topic 3: Stoics
item.description: Like Socrates’ vision of Philosophy and Epicureanism, Stoicism was for its ancient advocates most of all a way of living. Coming to understand what is really good, they argued, and how the good and happiness are rooted in nature, could lead us toward perfect lives. item.title: Topic 2: Epicureans
item.description: Epicureanism is a philosophy that focused on how to be a happy person, especially in the face of challenges, though its understanding of what happiness is differs from a lot of common, current ideas about happiness. Epicureanism became so popular that it became a dominant religion in the Mediterranean world, especially during the Roman empire. We will read the original Epicurean, Epicurus, and then the most prominent and influential Epicurean author, Lucretius, whose work De Rerum Natura is widely described as a classic of world literature.
